text:
At a gravity defying five degree angle the
leaning tower of Pisa is lucky it didn't end
up as a pile of rouble.
So why does the leaning tower lean?

Well the original foundations were just twenty
meters square by three meter deep, and set
on soft marshy ground.

Not ideal for fourteen point five tonnes of
marble on top.

It would be a bit like creating an eight tier
wedding cake and putting it on a tiny thin
plate and balancing it on fresh bread dough.

Now interestingly the original architect didn't
actually put his signature on the tower probably
because the project was doomed from the start.

Now pretty early on in the construction of
the tower, the builders realised that the
tower was actually leaning on the lower levels.

So they actually created the upper levels
at a slightly different angle going straight
up.

So if you look at the profile of the tower
now you'll notice it curves ever so slightly
a bit like a banana.

But still despite their best efforts over
time the tower continued to tilt and tilt
and tilt by a millimetre every year.

Until the early 1990's it was at so much risk
of toppling over because it was over five

degrees in angle that they actually had to
close it to the public.

Experts knew they had to come up with some
sort of solution.
Otherwise it was just going to topple over.

So they came up with a temporary fix which
they called the corset and the crutch.

And the corset was basically a metal structure
around the really vulnerable part of the tower.

While the crutch was ten tonne led weights
put on the ground next to the northern side

to counterbalance the overhanging southern
side of the tower.

The experts then realised they need engineers
to create a more permanent solution.

Now the outer wall and the inner wall of the
tower are made of marble but in between those
is a cavity filled with rouble.

So the engineers injected mortar into this
cavity to bind the rouble to the marble.

They also created a drainage system basically
because the water table kept fluctuating so

this made sure it didn't do that and actually
the ground stayed more stable.

They also closed all the wells in the local
area again so the water pumping didn't create
vibrations in the ground.

And finally they created an anchor system
with ten steel weights about forty five meters

down below the tower and then injecting liquid
nitrogen down into the soil around that to

try and freeze the ground and make it really
solid.

But for some reason it didn't work and the
tower, literally overnight, started tilting
more and more and more.

In a panic the engineers piled whatever heavy
stuff they could find from diggers to cranes

etc. on to the northern side the base of the
northern side of the tower and slung steel

cables from the top of the tower across to
the nearby cathedral.

Then they went back to the drawing board and
they decided they needed to dig out the foundations

from underneath the northern side in order
to make the foundations level.

So the removed, in the course of a year, about
a hundred kilograms of soil.
And it worked.

The tower only leans at about five degrees
now.

Now I've actually been up the tower and you
really do feel it leaning and get thrown against

the inside wall as you come around the northern
side and as you come around the southern side

you get thrown against the outside wall because
of the gravity.

But the view from the top is incredible and
the engineers claim the tower can survive
another three centuries.
Well see about that!
